required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Impact of Pack Supply on Birth Control Pill Continuation
clinical_study.official_title: Impact of Pack Supply on Oral Contraception Continuation

collaborator.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to determine whether getting more packs of birth control pills leads to improved continuation, when compared with getting the traditional supply.

detailed_description.textblock:
Discontinuation of oral contraceptive use in the initial months is common; successful early continuation is predictive of long term continuation and prevention of unintended pregnancy. The conventional approach to initiation of hormonal contraceptives in publicly funded clinics across the United States is to give the patient a limited supply of OCs, or a prescription with a limited number of refills, and then have her return to the clinic for a refill. This approach requires the patient to make frequent visits to the clinic, a barrier to method continuation.
This randomized trial will evaluate a simple but potentially powerful change in family planning clinic practice, i.e., the effect of dispensing more versus fewer cycles of oral contraception (OC). The study will be carried out in an urban, publicly funded family planning clinic that serves a population that is poor, young and primarily Hispanic or AfricanAmerican. This population was targeted as its members are at increased risk of discontinuing contraception in the ﬁrst year of use.

arm_group.description: enhanced initial supply of oral contraception
conventional initial supply of oral contraception

intervention.intervention_name: enhanced initial supply of oral contraception
intervention.description: 7 packs of pills, or 1 pack of pills and a prescription for 6 refills

intervention.intervention_name: conventional initial supply of oral contraception
intervention.description: 3 packs of pills, or 1 pack of pills and a prescription for 2 refills

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- English or Spanish speaker
- age less than or equal to 35 years requesting OC as their primary method of contraception
- currently sexually active or anticipating sexual activity within the next 30 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- contraindications to oral contraceptives per clinic protocol (e.g., hypertension and pregnancy)
- currently using OCs (that is, current users requesting a routine refill)
- desiring pregnancy within the next 6 months
- leaving the clinic catchment area within 6 months
- previous participation in this study

facility.name: Columbia University Medical Center, Family Planning Clinic

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology, Population and Family Health and Epidemiology at the New York-Presbyterian Hospital at the Columbia University Medical Center
